linkTarget.anchoringText: The sudden slip of a fault can first be analyzed as a semi-infinite plane strain shear dislocation as shown in Fig.1 (Rudnicki 1986).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Geometry of a semi-infinite plane strain shear dislocation

formatted-caption.caption-text: Geometry of a semi-infinite plane strain shear dislocation

linkTarget.anchoringText: A single inclined fault with a finite length of 2l1 and width of 2l2 is illustrated in Fig.2. Different from the illustration of Zoback (2010), the x and y axes are aligned with the orientation of the far field horizontal geo-stresses σH and σh, instead of azimuth.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: An arbitrary finite fault plane under shear dislocations

formatted-caption.caption-text: An arbitrary finite fault plane under shear dislocations

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order not to render the illustration of the calculated results overwhelming, the magnitude changes along the horizontal and vertical lines (in the global coordinate system) on the x-z plane passing through the center plane of the fault (the rectangle demarcated by the yellow dashed lines in Fig.3) are demonstrated in Fig.4 (a).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Transformation of the result from the local to global coordinate system

formatted-caption.caption-text: Transformation of the result from the local to global coordinate system

linkTarget.anchoringText: In order not to render the illustration of the calculated results overwhelming, the magnitude changes along the horizontal and vertical lines (in the global coordinate system) on the x-z plane passing through the center plane of the fault (the rectangle demarcated by the yellow dashed lines in Fig.3) are demonstrated in Fig.4 (a).

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Normalized (a) pore pressure at different Skempton's values; (b) mean stress, (c) octahedral shear stress and (d) pore pressure at different slip magnitudes

formatted-caption.caption-text: Normalized (a) pore pressure at different Skempton's values; (b) mean stress, (c) octahedral shear stress and (d) pore pressure at different slip magnitudes

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: pore pressure at different Skempton's values
pore pressure at different slip magnitudes

linkTarget.anchoringText: Along the z direction (marked by V) when passing the center of the fault, either stress or pressure is minimally affected by fault slip. Same phenomenon holds for Fig.4 (b)-(d) as well. The trends as discussed above (as well as the contours illustrated in Fig.5 (a)) are exactly in accord with Wang (1997) for the case where both θ and φ equal to zero.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Profiles of σ in the cases of (a) θ = 0, φ = 0; (b) θ = 30°, φ = 0; (c) θ = 30°, φ = 30° and (d) θ = 30°, φ = 60°

formatted-caption.caption-text: Profiles of σ in the cases of (a) θ = 0, φ = 0; (b) θ = 30°, φ = 0; (c) θ = 30°, φ = 30° and (d) θ = 30°, φ = 60°

linkTarget.anchoringText: To assess the influences of fault configuration on the stress and pressure perturbation, the strike and dip angles are varied among four scenarios: θ = 0, φ = 0 (the base case); θ = 30°, φ = 0; θ = 30 °, φ = 30°; θ = 30°, φ = 60°; other parameters being equal to those in Table 2. A NF condition with far field stresses σv = 35 MPa, σH = 30 MPa, and σh= 25 MPa is assumed to account for the role of strike angle. The mean normal stress σ and the octahedral shear stress τ after perturbation in the x-z plane passing through the center of the fault are demonstrated by Fig.5-6 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Profiles of τ in the cases of (a) θ = 0, φ = 0; (b) θ = 30°, φ = 0; (c) θ = 30°, φ = 30° and (d) θ = 30°, φ = 60°

formatted-caption.caption-text: Profiles of τ in the cases of (a) θ = 0, φ = 0; (b) θ = 30°, φ = 0; (c) θ = 30°, φ = 30° and (d) θ = 30°, φ = 60°

linkTarget.anchoringText: The FE analysis can tackle the conformance of deformation in between formations that stratigraphically vary in rock properties. It is also advantageous in that detailed stress and pressure fields can be predicted in a reservoir formed of several formations when field test data are quite limited. The stress and pressure disturbances attributed to finite fault slips can then be superimposed onto the stress and pressure fields derived from the FE analysis. The analytical process can be schematically depicted by the diagram in Fig.7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: A schematic diagram illustrating the analysis procedure of stress and pressure fields

formatted-caption.caption-text: A schematic diagram illustrating the analysis procedure of stress and pressure fields

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Weiyuan (shortened for W) region of Sichuan Basin in Sichuan Province, southwest China is currently experiencing booming development of its abundant shale gas reserves, mostly concentrated in the Silurian Longmaxi formation. The region is marked by the red polygon and the blue rectangles in Fig.8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Location map of the studied region

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location map of the studied region

linkTarget.anchoringText: The formation in the blue rectangle encompassing well W1 and W2 has a thickness of 280-450 m and a burying depth of 1525-3793 m. It is conformably in contact with the underlying Wufeng shale formation, whereas unconformity exists between it and the overlying Liangshan formation. The log records, fault information and the stratigraphy of the aforementioned formations in the selected regions are demonstrated in Fig.9 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Typical stratigraphy of the selected formations

formatted-caption.caption-text: Typical stratigraphy of the selected formations

linkTarget.anchoringText: The layout of wells W1 and W2 is displayed in Fig.10 (a). The red rectangle in Fig.10 (a) depicts the plan view of the domain used for the FE analysis, which has a dimension of 8.7 × 12 × 4.6 km from the ground surface down to the bottom layer (Fig.10 (b)). The σH is pointed in a direction of NE 139° normal to the two sides of the rectangle, which was determined from the orientation of the drilling-induced tensile fractures in W1 and W2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: (a) Layout of wells W1, W2 and (b) FE model to history match the stress field near W2

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Layout of wells W1, W2 and (b) FE model to history match the stress field near W2

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: FE model to history match the stress field near W2

linkTarget.anchoringText: The center of the fault is located at 1988 m southeast to the upper-left edge of the red rectangle (Fig.10 (a)), and 1695 m southwest to the upper-right edge of it, being 1175 m below the ground surface. The hanging wall is 5 m separated from the footwall producing an existing b2 slip of −5 m, while the slip on the other direction b1 is zero. The relative alignment of the fault with respect to well W1 is depicted in Fig.11 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Spatial alignment of the fault relative to well W1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Spatial alignment of the fault relative to well W1

linkTarget.anchoringText: The predicted stresses and pressure are compared among (1) using a combination of FE analysis and analytical solutions for the dislocation; (2) using the FE analysis alone without the effect of fault slip and (3) applying the classical methods on the log data (Haimson and Fairehurst 1967, Eaton 1969&1975). The corresponding results are demonstrated in Fig.12 for stresses and Fig.13 for pore pressure, respectively. The laboratory (using the Kaiser acoustic emission tests) and the XLOT measured data are presented in Fig.12 as well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of the predicted and measured stress values in W1

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of the predicted and measured stress values in W1

linkTarget.anchoringText: The predicted stresses and pressure are compared among (1) using a combination of FE analysis and analytical solutions for the dislocation; (2) using the FE analysis alone without the effect of fault slip and (3) applying the classical methods on the log data (Haimson and Fairehurst 1967, Eaton 1969&1975). The corresponding results are demonstrated in Fig.12 for stresses and Fig.13 for pore pressure, respectively. The laboratory (using the Kaiser acoustic emission tests) and the XLOT measured data are presented in Fig.12 as well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of the predicted pore pressure values in W1
